quoteLast: ,” replied Gideon Spilett directly. They had now only to calculate the operation. Nothing could be easier. It could be seen that there existed, in round numbers, a difference of five hours between the meridian of Washington and that of Lincoln Island, that is to say, it was midday in Lincoln Island when it was already five o’clock in the evening in Washington.
title: The Mysterious Island
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Kingston, Agnes Kinloch, 1823-1913 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Highlanders, had moved out from Wittekopslaager
quoteLast: , breakfastless, because it was thought that on reaching the river, which was but a short march of five miles off, there would be ample time for a meal. But by seven o'clock the fighting had begun. The General had arranged with the officer commanding the Royal Artillery to prepare the infantry attack with both batteries from the right flank, and the Infantry Division being still some miles distant, he gave them two distinct points to march on, which allowed of the brigades keeping in extended order and covering a very wide front.
title:

quoteFirst: All was right with such a man, in life or in death. The sea was now breaking completely over us, and we had to hold on the best way we could.

quoteLast: or half an hour before the main attacks), without any preliminary bombardment from the fleet upon the landing places.

quoteFirst: They set out once more. The silent and rapid ride recommenced. The night was gloomy and the riders glided through the shadows like phantoms. All night they galloped thus. At
quoteLast: they changed horses again at a half-ruined _rancho_. These men seemed made of iron; though they had been fifteen hours in the saddle, fatigue had no hold on them.

quoteLast: It was a very imposing sight. It moved first as one solid block, carrying boats, stacks of timber, sledge roads--everything--with it.

quoteFirst: When they got there, however, they found they were drawing so much shell fire that the R.E. officer decided not to proceed with the work.

The position of the Battalion now was two Companies in the Trench immediately behind North Station Buildings, and one Company in the strong points.

quoteFirst: Happily the gales blow with clockwork regularity, the day wind from the south and south-west rising punctually at 9 a.m. and attaining its maximum at 2.30, while the night wind from the north and north-east rises about 9 p.m. and ceases
quoteLast: Perfect silence is rare. The highly rarefied air, rushing at great speed, when at its worst deprives the traveller of breath, skins his face and hands, and paralyses the baggage animals. In fact, neither man nor beast can face it. The horses 'turn tail' and crowd together, and the men build up the baggage into a wall and crouch in the lee of it.
title: Among the Tibetans
author: Bird, Isabella L. (Isabella Lucy), 1831-1904; Whymper, Edward, 1840-1911 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Accordingly I marched immediately towards Montay in a thick drizzling rain, which made this dismal country appear ten times more dismal. The cavalry regiments marched at the same time (
quoteLast: ?) and we kept company as far as Montay; but there they left us, for we found the road again so choked with baggage, &c., that although we succeeded in passing the bridge, yet the deep hollow road (_encaissé_ between very high steep banks), ascending to the opposite heights, was so inextricably crammed with carriages, and the unctuous soil so slippery, that I feared we should bivouac in the churchyard again.
title: Journal of the Waterloo campaign, vol. 2 (of 2)
author: Mercer, Cavalié, 1783-1868

quoteFirst: Taking leave of my friends on board, I landed at
quoteLast: , and, having committed my luggage, a small bullock trunk, saddle-bags, and a saddle, to the shoulders of a sturdy facchino, and myself to a very rickety and diminutive cart, I proceeded on my way to Ragusa. The drive, about a mile and a half in distance, abounds with pretty views, while the town of Ragusa itself is as picturesque in its interior detail as it is interesting from its early history.

quoteFirst: Congratulations over, chairs are cleared away, rugs taken up and the room made ready for dancing till supper, Leschetizky playing for at least part of the evening. Toasts, speeches, stories, and laughter fill the hours till early morning, when,
quoteLast: , a happy, but exhausted, procession streams homeward, stopping on the way at some café--if it is not yet 6 o'clock--to make sure the hall-porter, with his dripping candle and everlasting demand for his ten-kreutzer fee, will be safely gone to his lair.
title: Theodor Leschetizky
author: Hullah, Annette
